RMP FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No RMP related accidents in the past 5 years. 



RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The facility maintains a written Facility Response Plan (FRP), which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire and/or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes.  Any changes are administered through the MOC process, which include informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.





The facility coordinates activities with the Lauderdale County Emergency Management Agency (EMA).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee with local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.   The facility has around-the-clock communication capabilities with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g.,fire department) to facilitate notification of the public and receive a quick response.  



Types of RMP site-specific prevention steps include the following:

-Release detection (e.g., process alarms, LEL monitors); and

-Release containment and control (e.g., pressure relief valves, manual and automatic shutoff systems, grounding equipment, check valves, and interlocks)





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in mod
ifications to the process to improve safety.
